required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Longitudinal Study for the Development of Innovative Wearable Tools for Foetal Wellbeing Monitoring
clinical_study.official_title: Longitudinal Study for the Development of Innovative Wearable Tools for Foetal Wellbeing Monitoring

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to support the development of a new generation of the Bloomlife sensor, enabling continuous monitoring of foetal wellbeing.
Data is collected in four Phases, with different experimental setups. Recordings with investigational and reference devices are performed on the subjects, at different gestational ages.
The collected data is used for developing algorithms for the extraction of parameters descriptive of foetal wellbeing.
Clinical information related to subjects' pregnancy and foetal health is also collected.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy and reliability in the detection of foetal heart rate
primary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout the subject's participation in the study, from inclusion until delivery
primary_outcome.description: Foetal heart rate is extracted from the collected electrophysiological data and compared to the reference

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy and reliability in the detection of foetal movements
primary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout the subject's participation in the study, from inclusion until delivery
primary_outcome.description: Foetal movements are detected from the collected sensor data and compared to the reference

arm_group.description: Data collections are performed with TMSi Porti system and CTG (reference)
Data collections are performed with the Bloomlife sensor and CTG (reference)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant
- Gestational age of at least 20 weeks
- Singleton pregnancy
- Willingness to participate in the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Multiple pregnancy
- Implanted pacemaker or any other implanted electrical device
- History of allergies to silicone-based adhesives
